Row.Text: Another face, another meeting. I greet you well friend. I am Tran Thanh Tong and this is my Empire, Dai Viet.
The mist parts and I greet you friend. Welcome to Dai Viet, a realm born of Dragons and Fairies. I am it's ruler Tran Thanh Tong.

You have fell my empire. You have killed my soldiers. And for what? The Viet people will remember. They will rise up again, as they have done in past. This is a shallow victory, you should enjoy it while you can.
You squander your words, they mean nothing to me in such number.
Yes yes, you wish to exchange goods and promises. I know.
What have we here? A fool come to waste the time of their betters?.
It is good to talk to you again. My gardens' flowers are in bloom, would you care to join me in appreciating their beauty while we discuss what you have come here for?
I am surprised you have not retreated your troops yet, as we both know you lack a spine. Dogs are not welcome in my court, please begone.
While Dai Viet is a land of peace, we can respect your valor. What is it you would like to discuss?
It is of course like you foreigners to take what you can, with no respect for your peers around the table. If only you could learn respect.
Your aquisitions threaten this careful peace we maintain. I would caution you to stop where you are.
I see your troops massing along the borders of my lands. I hope they are not there to stay. That would be unfortunate, for you.
A sauce spread too thin rarely has substance. A people spread too thin rarely has culture. Your new aquistions truely spread across the landscape.
Even my brother, the great general Tran Hung Dao, would be impressed by your magnificent army for it truely is a spectacle.
I eny your empire's ability to prosper in a world such as this. Perhaps we may arrange the exchange of mandarins to learn from eachother's good practices in economy.
Yes I see you petty warlord. No, I do not intend to make room in my court for your demands.
Dai Viet is a land of peace and culture. We seek not to fight, and only train the men we must. And yet, it would not take us but an issue to make your subjects our own. How are your forces so petty?
All great conquerers fall, this is the way of the world. Your turn may be next. Watch your stride.
I fear friend that I have not known you for very long, and we have yet to establish enough trust going forwards. Despite, I will happily share tea with you, as we create this trust further.
You are like the raging moonsoon. cruel, and simple. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])

I often wonder what leads terrible men to the leadership of peoples. They do not rule wisely, nor fairly, and are a stain on the reputation of their realm. Like you, for instance. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
I see that you feel as if we have done something wrong. You are incorrect.
I too enjoy the trust and company of {1_CivName}. May we all share tea and listen to the poets recite our glories.
You understand that {1_CivName} is a barbarian, no? They are worse than the plagued field that will grow no rice. And in this case, you are the rice and the field is your friendship.
You are without culture. {1_CivName} is a good friend of mine, and I know myself to be a good judge of friends. Your foolishness is a disgrace upon your empire.
I am glad you see the reason in calling upon the danger of {1_CivName}.
Your actions recently have been wise beyond years. {1_CivName} is someone who I have chosen to bestow my trust and friendship upon too.
Rats attract rats. The filth of the world settles in place together. You and {1_CivName} fit there well, in the cesspool.
{1_CivName} seeks to see this world we have built tarnished. I join you in international dialogue denouncing them.
You and I, we see the world through the same lense. Joining minds and hearts is something I wish.
Trust and friendship; I believe we have both. Shall we partake in tea to formalise our good terms?
Move you troops. Their position implies that they would wish to be undone by the forces of the Viets, which would not be wise on your part.
Do not think land you buy is land that can be kept. If it is intended to be Viet, it shall. And this land was intended.
Turn around now. Your settlers are too happy to take land that is not theirs to take.
I consider myself a man of great patience. Your expansion has worn it down. I prey you push it no further lest you see the might of Dai Viet.
I care not the might of your forces, you stand upon the land of the Viets and we cannot let you continue to!.
Karma is the divine telling of good, and you have gained much this day.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} announces to the world that it is now protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}. Attacking the City-State will greatly damage relations and may lead to war.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} has taken back its guarantee of protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}.
These are Viet lands. They will continue to be.
I seek only peace and prosperity for my people, and if agreeing to your terms is the path forward, I must.
The Viet people are industrious and artful. We seek to trade some of our wares, spendid they are, for yours.
Knowledge can only be obtained through experience. I wish to experience the sights of your lands and the hearts of your people, and you should mine.
Like leaves in the wind.
Do not think you frighten me. Dai Viet is prepared.
Truely, I had wished for war. No good Emperor should admit it, and no good emperor should send their people to it. You have given a good excuse today.
If only fate could lead another branch down the stream, the river would not have to be bloodied.
Ton Vu's writing prepares one for their enemies to come from within. While I hoped it would not come to this, I hope more that you expect the repercussions of what you have done.
This war is not done yet. You will not escape so easily into the mists of cowardice.
No, it will not be.
I agree, wisdom is in your choices.
